context_meta.summary: President Donald Trump has signed off on an executive order that would loosen rules on insurers, allowing them to offer “skimpy” health plans that would cover less but also cost less. But these actions seem certain to hurt some people as did Obamacare.

text:
I'm self-employed, over 60, under 65. The ACA was working just fine for me. I could count on the fact that it had all the basic coverage in place, with no hidden exceptions, and with no huge costs for being old (yeah, me) or sick (not really). I paid a reasonable amount for my insurance (no subsidies - I make enough to take care of my own needs).

Now, all of that is history because of Republican actions. Every insurance contract can be written (as they were pre-2013) to include a multitude of exceptions. Unless you read every line (yeah, I do), you'll find out about the exceptions when your daughter gets leukemia.

And, yeah, if you're 27 you possibly don't care if old folks pay 5x or more so that you can get cheap insurance. But you'll be old one day too. The ACA tried for a middle ground (3x for old folks) to spread the load. You pay a little more up front, you pay a little less when older (and more vulnerable to costs). Now all the rules are off.

You think that everything will work out fine - but no, it won't. These actions will break the individual health care market. The chaos that will ensue will cause irreparable damage to people - your sisters, brothers, aunts, uncles, and parents - and will make receiving real health care a function of how wealthy you are. Good luck with that.

text:
I worked for 45 years before retiring due to health issues. I was a tool maker, an engineer, and a quality manager during my career. My whole life I made a little better than average wages, was in the 3rd quintile of income. Without the ACA I would have been bankrupt, either from medical bills or from trying to pay upwards of $2000/month for health insurance premiums, along with a deductible of $5,000 or $6,000, and no maximum on out of pocket expenses. I would have been forced to pay whatever the insurance company offered at the end of COBRA coverage, because there would have been no other option due to pre-existing conditions. I know that because I was in that position when I ws running my own business in 2001.

I was on Obamacare insurance for 2 1/2 years, am now on Medicare. The insurance I had under Obamacare actually was better than my former employer had offered. When my wife had surgery last year for a condition that was leaving her completely incapacitated, I paid $4500 of a bill that approached $150,000. Under the plan my employer had, the bill would have been closer to $20,000. 

Obamacare has its faults, but it also offers help to millions of people like me, who worked hard their whole lives but who developed health issues later in life. Thank God that some people decided to do something to help the working man, and may those who are destroying that help realize what they are doing.

text: With no changes to Obamacare, this is the first year the enhanced federal funding for the Medicaid expansion starts to fade away and states will have to find new funds to pick up their share of the expense. As it turns out, “free money” comes at a cost. A report from the Foundation for Government Accountability (FGA) reveals that the fiscal pain coming to states may be even worse than anticipated.  In Ohio, Medicaid expansion ran $1.5 billion over budget in its first 18 months.  The state of Washington had to increase its biennium budget by $2.3 billion to deal with higher than expected Medicaid expansion costs and, having now surpassed even those revised projections, expansion overruns continue to climb.  Illinois’ Medicaid expansion ran $800 million over budget in 2014 and has now signed up more able-bodied adults than state officials predicted would ever be eligible.  In Kentucky, Medicaid expansion ran a combined $1.8 billion over budget in fiscal years 2014 and 2015. These states aren’t outliers. They’re the norm.

context_meta.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump's expected plan to let Americans buy insurance across state lines could violate federal law governing employee benefit plans and will almost certainly be challenged in court, several legal experts said. Trump said on Tuesday he would likely sign an executive order this week allowing people to cross state lines to obtain "great, competitive healthcare" that would cost the United States "nothing." The Republican president offered no specifics, but several sources familiar with the order said it was expected to be in the form of guidance to the U.S. Health and Human Services, Labor and Treasury Departments, which would be asked to look at ways that individuals and small businesses can band together to form "associations" that would buy large group health plans from states with the fewest regulations.

text: Trump 2020!

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Trump Signs Order To Undermine Obamacare Insurance Rules
context_meta.summary: President Donald Trump on Thursday signed an order that could rattle the Affordable Care Act’s private insurance markets by allowing a proliferation of cheaper, less comprehensive plans that would undermine rules about who and what insurers must cover.
